column3: Credential compromise - theoretical
column4: An adversary would compromise a function or service that has privileges to perform operations using the HSM and use other techniques to obtain the credentials. The adversary may perform operations from the compromised environment or exfiltrate the credentials to another system to perform the operations and conduct further activities.

column3: Depends on sub-technique

column2: Exploit Semi-public Facing Application or System
column3: None
Adversary may use the radio access network to determine that a particular UE is in the area, or where exactly the UE is located
column4: Multiple subtechniques exist

column3: Adversary may use the core network signaling to trigger the procedure of locating a particular UE via RAN
column4: Multiple subtechniques exist

column3: None

column2: Consume data allocation to deny or degrade service
column3: Malicious data consumption application
column4: Convince user to download or maliciously introduce application that consumes excessive data

column3: External AF uses legitimate SBA API to retrieve subscriber identifier of victim UE (SUPI) from their phone number
column4: AF calls Nnef_ApplyPolicy_Create API to NEF with UE's GPSI/phone number. NEF retrieves the SUPI from UDM by using Nudm_SDM_Get API. NEF stores the data in UDR and sends the requested data to AF. Section 4.15.6.8 of [1].

column3: Rogue NEF retrieves SUPI from GPSI/phone number using Nudm_SDM_Get API
column4: Section 4.13.2.2 of [1].

column3: Rogue AMF in visited PLMN retrieves UE’s sensitive information using Nsmf_PDUSession_ContextRequest API during 5GS to EPC roaming.
column4: AMF in visited PLMN calls Nsmf_PDUSession_ContextRequest API to v/hSMF. SMF sends the UE SM context in response which can reveal the following UE information: SUPI, S-NSSAI, DNN, UE IP address etc. Section 4.11.1.2.1 & Table 5.2.8.2.10-1 of [1])

column3: Control plane signaling storm from (at least) one malicious UE (source: experience of employee of large MNO, and who was responsible for threat handling).
column4:
Because network slices and network functions can be shared, malicious UE can create control plane storms.

AMF Message Flooding for a shared slice with shared NFs:
(1) An initial AMF validates if the user (UE) is allowed to access the subscribed S-NSSAI: AMF contacts the UDM to request the UE’s Slice Selection Subscription data.  The initial UDM may contact the UDR for the UE's Slice Selection Subscription data, then provides the data to the AMF.
(2) During the t0 to t-delta time interval that it takes to perform (1), the UE drops the initial AMF then re-attaches to the AMF, restarting the validation.
(3) The UE recursively performs (2), which recursively performs (1), creating a "UE-AMF-UDM-UDR-AMF" message storm sandwiched in between an "Attach-Detach" storm.
(4) Since this is a shared slice with shared NFs, the control plane storm (Attach-UE-AMF-UDM-UDR-AMF-Detach-Attach-recursively repeat) creates a DoS condition.

column2: Alteration of subscriber  profile charging parameters
column3: AMF/SMF can use Nudm_UECM_Update to modify UE context in the UDM.
column4: AMF or SMF can change some parameters in the UE context (which is like a subscriber profile, but valid only for a session; Section 5.2.3.2.5 of 23.502. The parameters are: PEI, analyticsID (for NWDAF), UE capabilities, Intersystem continuity context, SMF+PGW-C FQDN

column2: Alteration of subscriber  profile charging parameters
column3: Rogue AF/NEF via UDM can modify UE’s config for a given external service (e.g. pay for video for a game today). When the victim UE changes state from idle mode to connected mode, it will receive the modified services which may be inferior to the services originally provisioned.
column4: NEF can use Nudm_ParameterProvision update service to update UE subscription data. Section 5.6.2.2 of TS29.503 & sections 4.15.6.2, 4.15.6.3, 4.15.6.3a of TS23.502.

column2: Alteration of subscriber  profile charging parameters
column3: Compromised OA&M can modify subscriber profile data in UDR
column4: Compromised GUI or CLI based attack on subscriber database in UDR

column3: Assuming control of a network function, ask the NRF for a SD until a legitimate response is received (vs. an error).
column4: Any “consumer NF” can ask the NRF for information with a guessed slice identifier, until a non-error response is returned. The NRF services that are candidates for this operation are (3GPP TS 29.510: discovery and Access token (Nnrf_NFDiscovery and Nnrf_AccessToken). For the Discovery service, in the GET NF instances, the parameters can be included “plmn-specific-snssai-list”, which contains the S-NSSAIs that are served by the NF supposedly being discovered. Then the 200OK result contains the IE NFProfile, which includes the S-NSSAIs.

column3: Self-location measurement
column4: Victim UE is using a system with null encryption oris bid down to a less secure protocol. UE geolocation or geolocation measurement data is passively observed or, if bid down, actively ordered through illegitimate signaling.

column2: DOS a UE via fake cellular base station
column3: Bidding Down induced DOS
column4: Victim UE is either actively or passive bid down to less secure protocol. Adversary acts as a man-in-the middle to deny service by (1) issuing registration reject messages or other orders to deny radio access, or (2) posing as a legitimate base station, but not relaying traffic to or from the intended recipient.

column3: Adversary with rogue base station bids-down UE and sends an Identity Request message to get back the IMSI
column4: When UE security profile allows bidding down, adversary denies service to 5G, bids down victim UE to less secure protocol, and then actively interrogates or passively intercepts unencrypted International Mobile Subscriber Identifier (IMSI)  for 2G/3G/4G or Media Access Control (MAC) for WiFi.

column3: SUCI is replayed by rogue UE or gNB to the network
column4: UDM needs to process repeated SUCI messages from the same UE which will eventually drain resources of UDM and cause DoS attack on legitimate UE. Sections 5.2.2.1.2 & 5.2.2.2.2 of [1]

column3: Tools exist for pen testing. Examples GTScan, SigPloit, SCTPScan and GTPScan.
AMF exploit for weakening encryption of user traffic over the air interface
column4: Adversary takes over the AMF and enables NULL encryption for NAS and AS for all UEs; or, changes one Security Mode Command procedure for a given UE to enable NULL encryption or NULL integrity. This can be followed by another attack behavior whereby eavesdropping can be done over the air interface for data and signaling. Sections 5.3.2 & 5.5.1 of [2]

column3: SMF misconfiguration exploitation via adversary controlled gNB or via SMF control directly.
column4:
Adversary makes the unauthorized change in the SMF CP & UP local policy to enable NULL encryption for CP & UP traffic. The SMF is not implemented to check (for every UE) that the local policy is the same as the UE policy stored in the UDM, and so the SMF lets the CP & UP traffic over the radio interface be protected via NULL encryption.
Alternatively, an attacker with control over a legitimate gNB, and who currently serves the UE, tells the SMF that the UE CP & UP policy is NULL encryption, and the (legit but not correctly implemented) SMF doesn’t check that against the local policy and lets the CP & UP data use NULL encryption.
These can be followed by another attack behavior whereby eavesdropping can be done over the air interface for data and signaling. Sections 5.3.2 & 5.5.1 of [2]

column3: Alteration of gNB configuration for AS encryption to enable NULL algorithms
column4: Adversary intentionally configures NULL encryption and integrity protection algorithm to have highest priority in gNB. Sections 6.7.3 & D.1 of [2]

column3:
Compromised source AMF sends incorrect UE context information to legitimate target AMF during
Initial registration & roaming or
Handover (N2 based)
column4: Source AMF sends null encryption and integrity protection algorithm information as part of the “UEContextTransfer” (initial registration & roaming) or “CreateUEContext” (N2 handover) service request messages. All UE data will be sent in clear text after registration or handover is completed. Sections 4.2.2.2.2, 4.9.1.3.1 & 5.2.2.1 of [3] The element in the UE context is the ueSecurityCapability which the rogue AMF sets to NULL only.

column3: Compromised source MME/AMF sends incorrect UE context information to legitimate target AMF during EPS to 5GS handover and roaming with and without N26 interface
column4:
Source AMF sends NULL encryption and integrity protection algorithm information as part of the “UEContextTransfer” or 
“RelocateUEContext” service request messages. All UE data will be sent in clear text after roaming or handover is completed. Sections 4.11.1.2.2.2, 4.11.1.3.3, 4.11.2.3 & 5.2.2.1 of [3] The element in the UE context is the ueSecurityCapability which the rogue AMF sets to NULL only.

column2: Control plane signaling disguise for C2
column3: Third party app (AF)- NEF - UDM as a data exfiltration channel
column4: The signaling AF to NEF to UDM and back from UDM to NEF to AF is used in several procedures. Example: NIDD (non-IP data delivery) (see section 4.25 of 3GPP TS 23.502), or VN (Virtual Network) group management  (see section 4.15.6 of 3GPP TS 23.502).

column3: EIR database compromise
column4:
Reference [1], DC-003, calls for the MNOs to employ an EIR. The rest of the attack is theoretical.
The AMF is the only function that checks the EIR based on permanent equipment id (PEI) using the API N5g-eir_EquipmentIdentityCheck_Get.

column3: AMF can ask the UDM via the Nudm_sdm API to retrieve subscription data for a given SUPI.
column4: AMF can extract subscription data (including NSSAIs) for any given UE SUPI by asking the UDM (uses Nudm_SDM_Get service  (SDM=SubscriberDataManagement)). The UDM does not check that that AMF is the one serving the UE, i.e. the AMF does not need to register itself first as serving the UE, via the Nudm_UECM_Registration Request. Table 5.2.3.1-1 of [1]

column3: Rogue AMF in visited PLMN retrieves UE’s sensitive information using Nsmf_PDUSession_ContextRequest API during 5GS to EPC roaming.
column4: AMF in visited PLMN calls Nsmf_PDUSession_ContextRequest API to v/hSMF. SMF sends the UE SM context in response which can reveal the following UE information: SUPI, S-NSSAI, DNN, UE IP address etc. Section 4.11.1.2.1 & Table 5.2.8.2.10-1 of [1]

column3: SMF can ask the UDM via the Nudm-sdm API to retrieve some session management subscription info for a given SUPI.
column4: SMF can send to UDM a nudm-sdm message and retrieve “Session mgmt subscription data”, i.e. DNN configuration for all network slices.

column3: UDM can look up any UE’s data or can see it in the UDR if a UDR is employed
column4: UDM can legitimately get UE subscription data from UDR.

column3: SMSF can get the UE subscription data for a given SUPI via the Nudm-sdm API.
column4: SMSF can get the UE subscription data via Nudm_sdm.

column3: NEF can get some of the UE subscription data for a given SUPI via Nudm-sdm API
column4: Same as above.

column3: None

column2: Trigger Fraud Alert to Deny Service
column3: Capture a registration attempt for a given UE, then replay it right away to a gNB much further away
column4: An adversary might deny RAN access to a UE by triggering a fraud alert through attempting simultaneous registrations at geographically impossible locations. When the UE security profile allows, the adversary can illegitimately use a known IMSI or, if a valid Subscriber Concealed Identity (SUCI) is known, use a legitimate SUCI for false registrations.

column3: Adversary uses the fake base station to broadcast spoofed configuration messages to UEs nearby
column4: Reference [2] (appendix B) contains a taxonomy of attacks against 5G UEs, passive and active. One concerns message attacks (fake MIB/SIB – Master Information Block/System Information Block)

column3: Adversary installs an illegitimate complete gNB and configures the power so as to appear strongest to a given UE in a particular location
column4: Reference [2]

column3: Adversary/fraudster/SIM boxers are effectively acting as an unlicensed and unregulated telecommunications carrier (pretends to be a legitimate telecom provider). Intercepts call & SMSs and re-routes
column4: Adversary intercepts call and routes it via the Internet as a VoIP call, to the SIMbox (instead of via a regulated MNO interconnect). See [3], [5]

column3: Adversary offers discounted call rates directly to end consumers, primarily through the sale of international calling cards. Intercepts call/SMS and reroutes.
column4:
Such cards have a number that the user must dial before she can dial the recipient’s number; this number will route to a number provided by a VoIP provider that points to the
SIMbox in the recipient’s country. See [3], [5]

column3: False charging
column4: In [1] section 5.3., Signaling Fraud: False charging over international signaling interconnection.

column3: Compromised or misconfigured switches or routers between RAN and core and between gNBs can disable integrity protection for CP & UP communication between RAN and core or between two gNBs
column4: Integrity protection can be disabled on N2 interface for CP, N3 interface for UP and Xn interface for CP & UP. Sections 9.2, 9.3 & 9.4 of [2]

column3: Adversary uses SS7 interconnect (IWF) to a 5G network without protection (firewalls, etc). to obtain UE location information
column4: From [3], there were recent successful attacks on SS7 whereby an attacker with access to the SS7 interconnection can find a user’s location, as well as billing data and Short Message Service (SMS) messages. In addition, the attacker can also eavesdrop on user data.

column3: Adversary gains control of a core network function and obtain location info for a given UE
column4:
Several NFs can be used, and each threat has different characteristics. They are:
* AMF case: get UE location legitimately from LMF (Nlmf-loc API). [Section 8.3 of TS 23.273]
* An adversary can modify AMF behavior so that it doesn't allocate a new 5G-GUTI to a given UE, so that that UE can be tracked via listening devices in the area.
* AF case: Incorrect implementation/configuration in NEF can allow a rogue application function (AF) to access UE location information using LMF services. [Section 6.1.2 of TS23.273]
* SMF case: SMF can obtain a UE's location whenever the AMF sends it a PDU update request:  Nsmf_PDUSession_UpdateSMContextRequest (which contains UE location info, which can be: E-UTRA or NR cell id, location timestamp, “geographicalInformation” in hex format as in TS 23.032, only ellipsoid point with uncertainty circle.) [section 5.2.8.2.6 of TS23.502]
* UDM case: UDM can legitimately ask the AMF for the location of a UE using Namf_Location service. [5.2.2.1 of TS23.502]
* UPF case: UPF has access to serving cell ID for UEs that are actively sending data (RRC connected).  
* NEF case: NEF can legitimately ask AMF Namf_EventExposure or ask GMLC directly - then GMLC gives the NEF a location report (Note: NEFs serve as location proxies to internal and external AFs in the same way GMLCs serve as proxies to external LCS clients). [5.2.2.1 of TS23.502]
* NWDAF case: NWDAF can get coarse UE location by subscribing to events from AMF. [5.2.2.1 of TS23.502]
* GMLC case: GMLC can legitimately ask the AMF for the location of a given UE using Namf_Location service. [5.2.2.1 of TS23.502]
* LMF case: can initiate location procedure with the UE. [6.11.1, 6.11.2, 6.11.3 of TS23.273]

column3: Malware “interacts with CDR databases” (possibly from the SMSC, which this malware infects).
column4: Data miner loaded by installation script. The script CDR s for certain IMSIs, the info therein is call metadata, i.e. time, duration, phone numbers.

column3: Numerous
column4: Numerous

column3:
Rogue or wrong configuration/implementation in gNB or UPF can cause existing TEID to be assigned to a new N3 reference point or PDU session.

Duplicate TEID allocation can happen during EPS to 5GS handover or roaming.
column4: Duplicate TEID can cause traffic disruption, charging issues and eavesdropping of legitimate subscriber data by adversary. Section 5.8.2.3 of [2], section 4.11.1.2.2 of [3]

column2: DOS a UE via gNB or NF signaling
column3: gNB control (or fake UE)
column4: Adversary with a fake UE can send a De-registration request to the victim UE's gNB with the victim 5G-GUTI. Or , adversary with a fake gNB can send  Deregistration request to the victim UE. Or, adversary with fake UE can try to register as the victim UE, and when the victim UE tries to RRC connect again, it will be rejected. See [2]

column2: DOS a UE via gNB or NF signaling
column3: AMF control
column4:
Adversary controlling AMF can cause authentication to fail or deny SMS service by deactivating SMS for a given SUPI [1]. Control of AMF can give an adversary the power to manipulate the AKA procedure between the AMF and any other UE, so that (at the simplest) the UE fails authentication and can't get services
Rogue or misconfigured NF modifies the registration accept message for legitimate subscribers to deny access to some or all services that are configured in their profile.

column2: DOS a UE via gNB or NF signaling
column3: SEAF control
column4: Adversary controlling SEAF: change the parameters exchanged back to the home network

column2: DOS a UE via gNB or NF signaling
column3: SMF control
column4: Adversary controlling SMF can release an existing PDU session or not create a new one; or send a  N4 Session Release request to UPF

column2: DOS a UE via gNB or NF signaling
column3: UPF control
column4: Adversary controlling UPF can send a report of PDU session inactivity, which results in de-activating the UE session. Or alter secondary authentication between DN AAA and SMF so it fails

column2: DOS a UE via gNB or NF signaling
column3: AUSF control
column4: Adversary controlling AUSF: produce incorrect AKA parameters or change data out of UDM

column2: DOS a UE via gNB or NF signaling
column3: UDM control
column4: Adversary controlling UDM: fail the SUPI de-concealing operation, UE key will be different and NAS SMC will fail (e.g., responding to SUCI deconcealment with an incorrect SUPI). See [3].

column2: DOS a UE via gNB or NF signaling
column3: ARPF control
column4:
Adversary controlling ARPF can
Alter the root key (K) or provide wrong root key for the UE
Generate wrong authentication vector (AV) during UE authentication procedure using EAP-AKA’ or 5G AKA.
Both will result in authentication failure for the UE.  [Section 6.1.3 of 33.501]

column2: DOS a UE via gNB or NF signaling
column3: UDR control
column4: Adversary controlling UDR: give UDM incorrect security parameters, or remove UE authentication status.

column2: DOS a UE via gNB or NF signaling
column3: PCF control
column4: Adversary controlling PCF: return a very restrictive policy for that UE.

column2: DOS a UE via gNB or NF signaling
column3: NSSF and NSSAAF control
column4: Adversary controlling NSSF and NSSAAF: deny UE access to a slice by mishandling NSSAI (saying it's unavailable) or altering authentication params so that auth procedure fails.

column2: DOS a UE via gNB or NF signaling
column3: CHF control
column4: Adversary controlling CHF: Send a message to SMF to start PDU session release.

column2: DOS a UE via gNB or NF signaling
column3: SMSF control
column4: Adversary controlling SMSF: DOS only on SMS for a given UE.

column2: DOS a UE via gNB or NF signaling
column3: 5G EIR control
column4: Adversary controlling 5G EIR can mark UE as stolen.

column2: DOS a UE via gNB or NF signaling
column3: Home PLMN or visited PLMN SEPP
column4: Adversary controlling home PLMN SEPP or visited PLMN SEPP can alter or discard registration request/response message and/or other signaling messages to deny access for a UE.

column3: Reportedly some operators do not allocate new 5G-GUTI every time the UE re-registers.
column4:
Several operators do not re-allocate GUTI often enough or they use predictable patterns.  
Exact 5G-GUTI refresh mechanism is left to implementation. Mandatory refresh of 5G-GUTI is to be done by AMF for initial registration, mobility registration update and network-initiated service request message due to paging. [Section 6.12.3 of 33.501]

column3: Disrupt service
column4: [2] 11.2.3 advocates for cabling security

column2: Fraudulent AMF registration for UE in UDM
column3: Adversary registers an AMF it controls as the one serving a given UE that just de-registered
column4:
Adversary controlling an AMF registers that AMF in UDM (via Nudm_UECM_Registration Request) as serving a given UE that de-registered. If the UDM implementation does not store the authentication status of UEs as de-registered, it will accept that AMF. Now that adversary controlled AMF can potentially mount other attacks 
Note that the UDM does not communicate with the AMF based on OAuth tokens. Since AMF to UDM signaling is part of the key UE control plane, it may be that they have a permanent TLS connection (TBC)

column3: Manipulate data between two PLMNs
column4: In one approach, the adversary, in a position on an IPX, could modify the messages between the vPLMN (visited PLMN) and hPLMN (home PLMN) if PRINS is used, resulting in possible information modification and/or disclosure.  Modification of an Information element (IE) could enable possible denial of service and/or information disclosure and this is addressed in FGT5029.

column3: Compromise SEPP and modify signaling it sends
column4: If the adversary controls a vPLMN SEPP they may modify signaling on N32 and/or generate requests to hPLMN NFs. The adversary controlled vSEPP could terminate TLS connections to hPLMN NFs and proxy requests as an adversary-in-the-middle, see T1157.502. Legitimate looking requests that could result in information disclosure or fraud may involve Value Added Service (VAS), e.g. VAS providing SEPP to the VPLMN

Active attack. The aLTEr attack that exploits the fact that LTE user
data is encrypted in counter mode (AES-CTR) but not integrity
protected, which allows us to modify the message payload.

column3: Triple Handshake
column4: (2014): if a TLS client connects to a malicious server and presents a client credential, the server can then impersonate the client at any other server that accepts the same credential. Concretely, the malicious server performs a man-in-the-middle attack on three successive handshakes between the honest client and server, and succeeds in impersonating the client on the third handshake. See e.g.

column3: Malware loaded into a Linux running SMSC server
column4: Data miner loaded by installation script. The script targets and saves SMS messages (the contents, the IMSI and the source  and destination phone number). This is highly targeted to given IMSI numbers (e.g., proponents of movements against the Chinese gov’t). (note: CDR s were also targeted for certain IMSIs, the info therein is call metadata, i.e. time, duration, phone numbers). [1,2]

column2: Redirection of traffic via user plane network function
column3: Control UPF or able to send an N4 signaling to it, redirect UE traffic
column4:
An UPF can legitimately instruct the gNB to send traffic to a different UPF.
Adversary can send a Session Modification Request to the UPF (if they know its IP address and can spoof the source) redirect user traffic from the UPF to an attacker controlled server. To accomplish this, the attackers need to
change the IP address in the Outer Header Creation
Field. [4]

column2: Redirection of traffic via user plane network function
column3: Control SMF, redirect traffic
column4: Adversary controlling the SMF can redirect existing uplink UE traffic by sending to UPF a N4 Session Modification Request (or: selecting another UPF- or, by sending to UPF another “Redirect server” [which the adversary controls] in the FAR in the N4 session (Cisco UPF-Config-Guide: “The UPF reports to the SMF whether it supports traffic redirection enforcement in the UPF through the UP-Function Features IE.”) Similarly, the SMF can send a session modification request to the UPF and redirect UE traffic (downlink) — See sections 4.4.1.2 & 4.4.1.3 of [5].

column2: Redirection of traffic via user plane network function
column3: Rogue AF or rogue/misconfigured NEF can redirect traffic to undesired destinations.
column4:
This service is designed for MEC applications for local processing of data traffic in order to reduce latency. However, this capability can be misused by rogue AF or rogue/misconfigured NEF. Section 5.6.7 Table 5.6.7-1 1st row 
“Traffic Description” of [6].

column3: Externals geolocation
column4: Adversary geolocates unknown UE using some combination of Direction of Arrival, Time-of-Arrival, and/or Frequency-of-Arrival of UE signal externals.

column3: Passive Identity Mapping Attack – Check ATT&CK, this might have addendums. (Network Sniffing, Technique T1040 - Enterprise | MITRE ATT&CK®). Both passive attacks are probably T040. Send email to Dr. Michaela to ask if these two attacks are already present and if they should be an addendum to T1040 or possibly sub techniques to something else.
column4: Passive attack. Match transient radio identities to more permanent network identities, identifying users in the cell and preparing the battlefield for follow on attacks.

column3: Unmask User Web Activities - this might have addendums. See comment in previous line.
column4:
Passive attack. Abuse the resource allocation as
a side channel to perform website fingerprinting that enables
the attacker to learn the websites a user accessed.

column3: ALTER Attack (DNS Redirection, may have addendums in ATT&CK). This might need to be its own technique or might be a sub technique under DNS Manipulation.
column4:
Active attack. The ALTER attack that exploits the fact that LTE user
data is encrypted in counter mode (AES-CTR) but not integrity
protected, which allows us to modify the message payload.

column3: Incorrect implementation/configuration or compromised SMS home router can allow bypass of the SMS location query messages.
column4: [Section 7.2.2 of GSMA NG.111]

column2: Unauthorized access to NEF via token fraud
column3: Existing OAuth 2.0 attacks
column4: Attacks that are applicable to machine to machine communication (so no email phishing attacks)

column3: SMF control
column4:
An adversary may control the SMF and assign the same SMF Charging Identifier to a device data flow as that of an existing victim device, to cause charging errors. 
 (section 5.1.4 & annex A.1 of 32.255).
The SMF can also pause charging for a given UE (even though not warranted), section 4.4.4. of TS23.502.
The SMF can also misreport 5G data used by a given UE.

column3: PCF control
column4: An adversary with control over the PCF can change policy so that UE is allowed to consume a service it was not subscribed to- but it will still be traceable to that UE. Section 4.3.2 of 23.503.

column3: CHF control
column4: An adversary with control over the CHF can ignore when PCF tells it that the spending limit for this subscriber has been reached,or can ignore the SMS records from the SMSF (SMSF uses POST to put in data), or the SMF itself for 5G data it reports. [TS 32.240]

column3: NEF control or Application Function (AF) control exploiting weak NEF
column4:
Adversary on AF can attack a weak NEF. Or, the NEF can be compromised and conduct this attack without even an AF. 
An AF can ask the NEF to change the “chargeable party” (TS29.522 section 4.4.8, TS29.122 section 4.4.4). This is meant to support the AF being the chargeable party, but it’s imaginable how the AF can put a different AF as chargeable: it has to send the AF identifier, UE IP address, Sponsor ID, ASP ID, etc. even AppID

column3: Compromised or misconfigured gNB or UPF can disable integrity protection for CP & UP communication between RAN and core or between two gNBs
column4: Integrity protection can be disabled on N2 interface for CP, N3 and N9 interfaces for UP and Xn interface for CP & UP. Sections 9.2, 9.3, 9.4 & 9.9 of [2]

column3: Cable/Copper Theft
column4: Copper’s value transforms remote cellular base stations into prime targets for thieves. The costs for telecom and tower operators to replace the cost of the cable and damage to the site can be thousands of dollars per incident. This is not taking into consideration the additional costs of loss of network service. Even the theft of a small amount of copper can cause extensive damage to site equipment, costing cell towers owners thousands of dollars in repairs, replacement, and network downtime. There are several expensive copper items at cell sites that are very attractive to thieves, such as the ground wires, copper grounding busbars, and waveguides

column3: Battery Theft
column4: Battery theft can easily become the root cause of cell services outage. Similarly, to the case of cable theft, telecom towers are increasingly affected by the rise of battery theft and vandalism.

column3: Fuel Theft
column4: Fuel is a major asset at telecom sites that can easily and directly be sold by thieves. The threat of diesel theft is widespread in many emerging markets and even in the rural areas of the developed markets

column3: Agency (GHCQ) infiltrated SIM vendor’s (Gemalto) network.
column4: Allegedly: GHCQ planted malware on Gemalto servers to obtain SIM credentials. The number of keys are in the order of millions. [1]

column3: Tools exist for pen testing. Examples GTScan, SigPloit, SCTPScan and GTPScan.
API used is Nnrf_NFManagement
column4: Adversary uses this API to register one of these functions: AMF, SMF, UDM, AUSF, NEF, PCF, SMSF, NSSF, UPF, etc. Clause 5.2.7 of [3]

column3: Malicious NF belonging to compromised Slice gets an access token for the target AMF, which servers both target slice and compromised slice.
column4: Malicious NF of a compromised slice gets access token for a shared AMF, but then asks AMF for the location of a UE in the target slice. The AMF checks that the authorization (OAuth) token is ok, which it is, but does not check that the UE ID is served by target slice, while the requester NF is from compromised slice.

column2: Exploitation of Interconnect Edge Application Programming Interfaces
column3: Denial of Service
column4: The SEPP can be overloaded with API calls if it does not apply rate limiting.

column2: Exploitation of Interconnect Edge Application Programming Interfaces
column3: Sensitive data exposure
column4: Adversary uses an insecure API to take over the edge NF, then can use legitimate signaling to obtain sensitive UE or network data.

column3: IR.21 accessible from the Internet
column4: Claro Americas, and Vivo telecom, had in 2016 their IR.21 database accessible from an internet  (links [2], [3] no longer accessible)

column3: Passive Identity Mapping Attack – Check ATT&CK, this might have addendums. (Network Sniffing, Technique T1040 - Enterprise | MITRE ATT&CK®). Both passive attacks are probably T040. Send email to Dr. Michaela to ask if these two attacks are already present and if they should be an addendum to T1040 or possibly sub techniques to something else.
column4: Passive attack. Match transient radio identities to more permanent network identities, identifying users in the cell and preparing the battlefield for follow on attacks.

column3: Unmask User Web Activities - this might have addendums. See comment in previous line.
column4:
Passive attack. Abuse the resource allocation as
a side channel to perform website fingerprinting that enables
the attacker to learn the websites a user accessed.

column3: Adversary-in-the-Middle on air interface for a given UE
column4: The adversary employs a back to back gNB-UE combination. When UE security profile allows bidding down, adversary denies service to 5G, bids down victim UE to less secure protocol with illegitimate signaling, acts as a man-in-the-middle to intercept and possibly modify communication, and relays communication to and from intended recipient.

column3: Adversary-in-the-Middle on air interface for any UE
column4: Alternatively, if the 5G system employs null integrity or encryption, user data traffic can be eavesdropped or modified in transit over the air interface

column3: Communication center: unauthorized access, destruction of assets and impairment of operations
Telecommunications equipment room:  unauthorized access, destruction of assets and impairment of operations.
Physically isolated operation areas: unauthorized access, destruction of assets and impairment of operations
Equipment sited in other carrier's or partner's premises: unauthorized access, destruction of assets and impairment of operations.
Fake gNB with stronger signal strength than legitimate gNBs sends RRC redirection that is not integrity protected.
column4: UEs tend to attach to gNBs which have better signal condition than the gNB the UE is currently attached.

column3: Intercept home network over the air.
column4: Receive SUCI and extract home network, which is never concealed.
